I LEFT THE CONVENTION AND THE BOARD MEETINGS WITH THE FEELING THAT
MEMBERS WERE MORE VOCAL AT THIS PARTICULAR MEETING. THEY EXPRESSED WANTS
AND EXPRESSED THESE IN THE FORM THAT THE BOARD COULD TAKE SOME ACTION ON,
The Board recognized these wants and has taken positive steps to implement
them. Certainly a great cjdeal of good should come from the Philadelphia
MEET ING.
Of particular interest to the radio station operators was the approval
IN PRINCIPAL OF THE NEW OPERATING MANUAL FOR THE NAEB NETWORK. THE RADIO
BOARD AND THE FULL BOARD GAVE ADDITIONAL POLICY DIRECTIONS TO THE DRAFTERS
OF THIS DOCUMENT WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO SUBMIT IT BACK TO THE FULL BOARD BY
THE FIRST OF DECEMBER, TO THE MEMBERSHIP BY THE FIRST OF THE YEAR, WITH
REACTION TO BE IN AND A REVISED DRAFT READY FOR PRESENTATION TO THE BOARD
AT ITS SPRING MEETING IN COLUMBUS IN MAY. FINAL DISTRIBUTION SHOULD BE
made by July I, 1963. This document should regularize all network pro-
cedures and should make it exceedingly easy for managers of stations
A
affiliated with the network to understand the operation of this complex
PIECE OF MACHINERY, AND TO ENABLE THEM TO TAKE THE BEST ADVANTAGE OF THE
SERVICES PROVIDED.
The main topic in the television area was whether NAEB should do any
PRODUCTION IN THE TELEVISION FIELD. At SEVERAL REGIONAL MEETINGS AND AT
THE TELEVISION STATION MANAGERS MEETING STRONG OPPOSITION WAS VOICED TO
THIS, BASED ON THE FEELING THAT ONE ORGANIZATION IN THE EDUCATIONAL
TELEVISION PRODUCTION FIELD WAS ENOUGH, AND THAT NAEB HAD A JOB TO DO TO
WORK FOR THE TELEVISION STATIONS IN AREAS OTHER THAN PRODUCTION, AND THAT
IT NEEDED TO SPEND MORE TIME IN DOING THIS JOB. OTHERS FELT THAT NAEB
